## Step 1: Load Required Libraries

```{r}
library(ggplot2) #plotting
library(tidyverse) #data wrangling
library(phyloseq) #phyloseq objects
library(dplyr) #data wrangling
```

# ITS SF

### Step 2: Load Feature Table, Metadata, and Taxonomy

\### Loads a feature table (OTU table), where rows = OTUs, columns =
samples. \#### pivot_longer(...): transforms it from wide format (OTUs
vs. many samples) into long format, where each row is a single
OTU-sample pair. \#### metadata: sample-level information (site, depth,
etc.) \#### taxa: taxonomy annotations per OTU

```{r}
merged <- read_csv("/Users/kyasparks/Desktop/CSU 2023-2024/Projects/ASCC/ASCC_July2024_USETHIS_ks/ITS/ITS_denoise_files/ASCC_ITS_feature_table_rem_RELABUND.csv") %>% 
  pivot_longer(names_to = "samples", values_to = "Relative_Abundance",2:305)

metadata <- read.delim("/Users/kyasparks/Desktop/CSU 2023-2024/Projects/ASCC/ASCC_July2024_USETHIS_ks/ITS/ITS_metadata/ASCC_ITS_metadata_rem.txt") 

taxa <- read.delim("/Users/kyasparks/Desktop/CSU 2023-2024/Projects/ASCC/ASCC_July2024_USETHIS_ks/ITS/ITS_taxonomy/taxonomy_ITS_ASCC.txt")
```

## Step 3: Merge Datasets

### Youâ€™re combining:

\#### 1. OTU table + metadata (by sample ID) \#### 2. Then adding
taxonomy (by OTU ID) \##### Final result: a â€œlong-formatâ€ data frame
with OTU abundance, taxonomy, and metadata per row. \####

```{r}
data_meta <- inner_join(merged, metadata, by =c("samples"="samples"))
data_meta_taxa <- inner_join(data_meta, taxa, by =c("OTUID"="OTUID"))
```

## Step 4: Subset to Site = SF

```{r}
SF <- subset(data_meta_taxa, Site == "SF")
```

## Step 5: Calculate Average OTU Relative Abundance

### Group by OTUID and Phyla

\#### Calculates total abundance across samples for each OTU \####
Divides by the number of samples to get mean abundance of each OTU
across SF samples

```{r}
avg_rel_abund_per_otuid <- SF %>%
  filter(!is.na(Phyla) & Phyla != "") %>%  # Ensure no missing values
  group_by(OTUID, Phyla) %>%  # Group by OTUID and Phyla
  dplyr::summarize(
    total_relative_abundance = sum(Relative_Abundance, na.rm = TRUE),  # Sum relative abundances across samples
    num_samples = n_distinct(samples),  # Count the number of unique samples
    avg_relative_abundance = total_relative_abundance / num_samples,  # Calculate average relative abundance
    .groups = "drop"
  )
```

## Step 6: Find Top 10 Phyla

### Group OTUs by Phyla

\#### Take the mean of their average OTU abundances \#### Sort to find
the top Phyla \#### Store the names of the top 10 most abundant Phyla,
which will be used to filter the plot later

```{r}
avg_rel_abund_per_Phyla <- avg_rel_abund_per_otuid %>%
  group_by(Phyla) %>%
  dplyr::summarize(
    avg_relative_abundance = mean(avg_relative_abundance, na.rm = TRUE),  # Sum average relabundances across OTUs
    .groups = "drop"
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_relative_abundance))  


top_10_phyla <- avg_rel_abund_per_Phyla %>%
  slice_max(order_by = avg_relative_abundance, n = 10)

# Extract the names of the top 10 Phyla
top_10_phyla_names <- top_10_phyla$Phyla

print(top_10_phyla)
```

## Step 7: Filter Full SF Data to Only Top 10 Phyla

```{r}
data_top_10_phyla_SF <- SF %>%
  filter(Phyla %in% top_10_phyla_names)
```

## Step 8: Define Custom Color Palette

```{r}
# Combine top 10 phyla from all three sites
top_10_SF <- data_top_10_phyla_SF$Phyla
top_10_TP <- data_top_10_phyla_TP$Phyla
top_10_SJ <- data_top_10_phyla_SJ$Phyla

# Combine and get unique phyla
all_top_phyla <- unique(c(top_10_SF, top_10_TP, top_10_SJ))
```

```{r}
# Make sure you have enough colors
color_vector <- c(
  "#3B1911", "#6D2F20", "#A8402D", "#B75347", "#DF7666","#DE6000","#D89241",
  "#EDC756", "#EDE955", "#C5F08D", "#B5C775", "#7C9659", "#70B59A", "#2D928F","#2C776F","#234E61","#193745","#0A161C" # extra if needed
)

# Named vector for consistent mapping
phy_colors_named <- setNames(color_vector[1:length(all_top_phyla)], all_top_phyla)

# Add color for "Other"
#phy_colors_all["Other"] <- "lightgray"
```

```{r}
plot_data <- data_top_10_phyla_SF %>%
  mutate(
    Depth = factor(Depth, levels = c("OM", "0_5cm", "5_15cm")),
    Phyla = factor(Phyla, levels = all_top_phyla)  # ðŸ‘ˆ this is what ensures all 16 show in the legend
  ) %>%
  group_by(samples, Phyla, Depth) %>%
  summarise(
    Relative_Abundance = sum(Relative_Abundance, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Clean up phylum names before setting factor levels
plot_data <- plot_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(Phyla), Phyla != "") %>%  # remove empty or NA
  mutate(
    Phyla = factor(Phyla, levels = all_top_phyla),
    Depth = factor(Depth, levels = c("OM", "0_5cm", "5_15cm"))
  )
```

```{r}
sf_plot <- ggplot(plot_data, aes(x = samples, y = Relative_Abundance, fill = Phyla)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  facet_wrap(~Depth, nrow = 1, scales = "free_x") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = phy_colors_named, drop = FALSE) +  # this is key
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(scale = 1)) +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 75, hjust = 1, size = 6),
    legend.position = "right"
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Samples",
    y = "Avg Relative Abundance",
    fill = "Phyla"
  )
print(sf_plot)
ggsave(filename = "/Users/kyasparks/Desktop/CSU 2023-2024/Projects/ASCC/ASCC_July2024_USETHIS_ks/ITS/ITS_taxonomy/sfbarchartsits.svg",
       plot = sf_plot,dpi = 300, device = "svg")
```
